title: Metrological Analysis of Sunflower Prototype
abstract: It is well known that the solar tracking systems can increase the efficiency of the photovoltaic (PV) panel by about 30 percent. However, these systems require precise control of their components, mainly of the equipment’s used for the measurement of energy. In this paper, a metrology analysis is conducted, through of the results obtained by Sunflower prototype. The Sunflower is a solar tracking system developed by H. J. Loschi. A tracking system through a microcontrolled timing logic, sending commands to a linear actuator that moves the system. The deductions, based on in research trials, confirms that the Sunflower prototype is more efficient in relation to fixed PV panels, it is possible to observe the difference in the efficiency of 31%, with a variation of ±0.8% (that depends the solar irradiation). The main purpose of this paper is to attest to the quality of the measurements carried out during the performance tests of the Sunflower prototype, evaluating the uncertainty of measurements collected through the measurements equipment, and, introducing methods to minimize uncertainties of measurement equipment in the PV systems.

motivations: Solar tracking systems require precise control and measurement to maximize efficiency gains.
There is a need to evaluate and minimize the uncertainty of measurement equipment in photovoltaic (PV) systems.
objectives: Conduct a metrological analysis of the Sunflower prototype to assess its efficiency and measurement quality.
Evaluate the uncertainty of measurements collected through the measurement equipment.
Introduce methods to minimize uncertainties of measurement equipment in PV systems.
methods: Analyze the results obtained from the Sunflower prototype's performance tests.
Assess the efficiency of the Sunflower prototype in relation to fixed PV panels.
Evaluate the uncertainty of measurements using metrological analysis techniques.
results: The Sunflower prototype is 31% more efficient than fixed PV panels, with a variation of ±0.8% depending on solar irradiation.
The metrological analysis confirms the quality of the measurements carried out during the performance tests.
Methods to minimize uncertainties of measurement equipment in PV systems are identified.
llama_json.research_subject: Metrological analysis of the Sunflower solar tracking system prototype

motivations: Solar tracking systems can increase the efficiency of photovoltaic panels, but require precise control of their components.
There is a need to evaluate the quality and uncertainty of measurements in solar tracking systems.
objectives: Conduct a metrological analysis of the Sunflower prototype, a solar tracking system.
Evaluate the efficiency of the Sunflower prototype in comparison to fixed photovoltaic panels.
Introduce methods to minimize uncertainties of measurement equipment in photovoltaic systems.
methods: Use a microcontrolled timing logic to send commands to a linear actuator that moves the system.
Evaluate the efficiency of the Sunflower prototype through research trials.
Assess the uncertainty of measurements collected through the measurement equipment.
results: Confirm that the Sunflower prototype is more efficient than fixed photovoltaic panels.
Identify a variation in efficiency that depends on solar irradiation.
Provide methods to minimize uncertainties of measurement equipment in photovoltaic systems.
openai_json.research_subject: Metrological analysis of the Sunflower solar tracking system

motivations: Solar tracking systems can significantly increase photovoltaic panel efficiency, but require precise control and accurate measurement of energy components.
There is a need to validate the measurement quality and assess uncertainties in solar tracking system performance evaluations.
objectives: Conduct a metrological analysis of the Sunflower solar tracking prototype to validate measurement quality and assess measurement uncertainties.
Introduce methods to minimize measurement uncertainties in photovoltaic systems.
methods: Perform metrological analysis through experimental trials using the Sunflower prototype, which employs microcontrolled timing logic and linear actuators for solar tracking.
Evaluate measurement uncertainties from equipment used during performance tests of the solar tracking system.
results: The Sunflower prototype demonstrated 31% higher efficiency compared to fixed PV panels, with a variation of ±0.8% depending on solar irradiation.
Validated the quality of measurements and identified methods to minimize measurement uncertainties in PV systems.
anthropic_json.research_subject: Metrological analysis of solar tracking systems for photovoltaic panels
